Posts.Content: Yes, the reason these two are not used for pre-menopausal women is because in pre-menopausal women the majority of the estrogen they produce is produced from the ovaries, in post-menopausal women this is not the case as their ovaries have ceased to function as such. The aromatase enzyme which is involved in the synthesis process can be found in many places from the reproductive orgrans to the skin and bone in a woman.  Hence they are 'aromatase' inhibitors which means they try to inhibit the aromatisation of androgens into estrogens by interrupting the synthesis of the same whereas Tamoxifen will be used for pre-menopausal women to 'block' the estrogen receptors rather than the production of estrogen. But not sure any of this answers Sascha's question.  From what I know, As there is little difference (except in side effects) between the two with regards to what they do, which one is prescribed is really matter of choice for the doctor doing the prescribing.  I think I said in a previous post that letrozole has been proven to very minimally give better results for breast cancer but yes the side effects can be worse.  So in effect, if you are on one and you suffer too much, your doc should be able to switch you over to the other.

Posts.Content: Hi, hope I am not too late. 1.  Prevention is better than cure with T.  Water water water.....  Your body needs water to do anything include breathe so drink lots of water while receiving your chemo intravenously and drink at least 2 litres a day for at least a week afterwards.   2.  Rinse your mouth several times a day with a warm salt water solution and/or Difflam or similar to minimise or avoid the swelling and furry tongue you may get which affects taste, can be painful and affects your appetite. 3.  Scout time - be prepared with painkillers (and paracetamol just wont cut it, not matter what the nurse may say).  I would ask the hospital for a prescription for tramadol or gabapentin so that you have them on hand.  If you don't need them - great but if you do, take them immediately upon the first twinge as the pain will get worse not better. 4.  Eat plenty of plain foods more fruit and veg than carbs as these also contain water but are also more nutritious.  5.  Take rest as and when you need it.  The first is normally the worst, after that you should be doing ok, until the next time!!  6.  As Rebecca has found out, the steroids will keep you  very alert for the first 48 hours or so, do something useful, get a good book or something, because you just wont sleep the first couple of nights.

Posts.Content: Cerijune, First of all,I am really surprised nbody has replied to you yet but welcome and sorry that you find yourself on this forum but glad that you came here instead of trying to deal with this alone. I was diagnosed with a grade 2 breast cancer in November last year and just like you, it was suggested that I have neo-adjuvant (pre-surgery) chemo to shrink the significant size of the lump (8cm x 7cm) in order to 1.  see if the lump reduces to a size which makes it possible to save the breast by a lumpectomy instead of a mastectomy and 2. if not, make the surgery a lot easier. You simply cannot expect or prepare for something in life like this.  It is a blow to everyone of us who have been diagnosed with breast cancer.  It really is a case of dealing with it when it comes and we all feel initially that we cannot cope.  Initially the chemo scared me, now i am half way through, it seems insignificant.  Now the surgery looming scares me but I am sure I will feel the same way about that once it is done.  It is a long pathway through treatment to get to recovery so taking one step at a time is the only way. The treatment they suggest is only that, a suggestion.  You of course have the right to refuse any or all treatment but you need to do so when you are fully informed.  It sounds like you need to talk to your oncologist or bcn and ask every question possible to fully understand why and how etc.  When I was given my news, I was given it by a doctor who seemed quite detached and unsympathetic and the way he explained things to me I thought I had no options and that mastectomy was going to happen no matter what etc.  However, the next doctor I saw (who will be my surgeon) explained things in quite a different way.  I also think I must have one of the best oncologists out there (not that I have a lot of experience with them), he has been so lovely and patient and answered every question I throw at him.  His name really is apt Dr. 'Goodman' as he really is a good man. For one, you cannot be expected to prepare for this when you feel so confused and for another you will be confused until you are fully informed.  Talk this over with someone first (maybe call the macmillan helpline - their nurses are lovely) and then prepare a long list of questions you need answering for your specific case and ask them of your medical team. You are allowed to panic and be afraid.  We have all been there - lean on us, lean on friends and family because you will need support through this no matter what you choose to do. I hope you stay on the forum and get the support you need here.  Good luck. XX

I do hope someone who has gone through the same situation can answer your question but your BCNs should also have some stats on the effects of RT on implants in cases at your hospital, they may even be able to put you in touch with someone who has been there and done that, so ask them. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Immediate reconstruction followed by radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Michelle, The PICC line is definitely a bonus.  It takes about 5 mins to put in place (then you have an xray to check its in the right place).  Mine took a couple of weeks to settle, the insertion point kept bleeding and I had to have the dressings changed every other day but once it settled it was fine.  It can seem a bit cumbersome but you get used to it and it makes having chemo so much easier.  No pain, it comes out in 10 seconds and leaves a tiny scar which heals over quick enough. I had my 3 Docetaxel through a canula and only my 3 FEC through the PICC, I so wished I had had the PICC line at the beginning.   So long as you are careful and wear the stretchy dodah over it to keep it in place, you soon forget its there and just get on with things. XX
Posts.Title: Finished my treatment today!

Posts.Content: Well my official journey started 30 November 2011 when I was diagnosed.  Since then I have had 3 courses of Docetaxel, 3 courses of FEC, A picc line, Single MX and immediate LD Flap recon and 15 days of Rads.  Today was my last rad and I now I am on 5 years (possibly to be increased to 10) of Anastrazole.  But my journey is not at an end, apparently!  I have to have blood tests every 3 months to check my estrogen levels, possible removal of ovaries, annnual mammograms and all the rest of the crap that this journey throws at you.  It has been 9 months so far (usually 9 months signifies creating life,but in this case, it hopefully signifies the death of something!). I am feeling surprisingly hopeful and positive, despite the financial and practical implications this disease has left me with but I am ready to start planning a future for me and my three children aged 11, 8 and 3. I just wanted to share this with any of you still muddling through.  It is possible to come out the other end with some positivity even if things seem hard at the time.  it most certainly has not been an easy 9 months but it's my birthday next month and I plan to enjoy it! Stay strong ladies, if I can do, we all can!  XXX

Posts.Content: Joanne, the pains you describe were exactly what I suffered on my first taxotere cycle.  I cried in agony from the back pain, which made me unable to stand, walk, sit or lay in bed without pain.  It lasted 2 days for me, with milder hip joint pains when I walked for about 3 days after that.  I told my oncologist about this and he immediately prescirbed gabapentin for me to take for 7 days starting the day after chemo.  I had no side effects whatsoever last time and asked for gabapentin again today so I hope this cycle will be as easy. its strange but I hear of so many on here who onc just says take ibruprofen or similar, perhaps even codine but the pains are neuropathic not muscular which I find strange.  Gabapentin is a drug that was originally used for epilepsy because it works on the nerve endings and controls spasms but was found to ease neuropathic pain and I assure you it works 100%!  Please ask your onc for next cycle.  Maybe I just have the kindest onc in the south. The diarrhea is normal but you should tell your doctor if it is excessive.  drink plenty of water (I usually go through 2litres a day on the first week) it helps flush the chemo drugs through your system quicker and will help with side effects. I am looking forward to FEC for my next 3 cycles as these is supposed to be a walk in the park compared to T!   Good luck.

As for the burning sensations, not sure, could be due to the chemo effect on your skin and causing some sensitivity.  I am having that at the moment on my hands and face after 3 cycles.  My skin is extremely dry and sensitive and my face all red and blotchy as are the backs of my hands and knuckles. Anything you are worried about, you should call your care nurse(s) I am sure they will put your mind at rest or ask you to see a doctor if they feel concerned.  Never feel that your concerns are too minor - its not like we go through this every day is it, but they do!

Posts.Content: Evening annie, Yep like you I am a vegetarian with a small 'v'. i.e. I like to eat fish.  I love beans and lentils in soups, chilli and other stuff.  I do occasionally have a takeaway but only occasionally.  Just before I was diagnosed I noticed that I was craving really sweet stuff and I never had a sweet tooth.  In fact, I used to love to eat a jar of pickles and then drink the vnegar (yuk) and eat whole lemons rather than cakes and sweets and while going through chemo I found it pretty hard to stick to the healthy eating as your tastebuds become non existent and its almost like existing through comfort eating but since finishing, I am back on the wagon.  SO I would not worry too much.  It is only a temporary thing and once you life gets a bit more stable as treatment progresses, you should find that you are more able to do the right things again. Don't feel guilty, its not like this is going to be the way your life is forever is it?  I think with what you are dealing with you are entitled to fall off the wagon and go haywire.  Just eat whatever makes you feel good at the moment and be good when you can.  You have to do what you have to do to get through it.  there is so much pressure on you already, dont push yourself too much.  Let go for a while. Posts.Content: Lynne, Thats a fair point that was made about the cold cap.  Although I have not used one and was never offered one, I had heard that having your hair short so that the cold cap gets as close to your scalp as possible definitely works better.  A bit late for you however but don't worry, as Helen said, it now takes me 25 minutes to get ready as opposed to an hour previously because I no longer have to wash and blow dry and faff with my hair (bonus no1), also I don't spend as much at Boots on haircare as I was, particularly as I often used to get fed up with a shampoo and conditioner and opt for a different one before my other one was finished (bonus no 2) and although I bought a wig at the beginning, I wore it once and did not feel comfortable so i just wear a bandana at the moment.  My favourite one is a beaded padded front bandana from Bohemia-fashions.com and although my daughter calls me the 'psychic pirate' when I wear it, i get lots of compliments when I am out as they find the beaded ends quite feminine apparently and different. I, too, am really looking forward to my hair growing back as I hear that 8 times out of 10 if you had straight previously you could end up with curly hair when your new crop grows.  I have always wanted curly hair and have spent a fortune on perms and curling tongs in the past so I have my fingers crossed.  my daughters are also keen to see if it grows back the same colour or not!!  Its quite exciting.  How often can a woman have a hairstyle and hair colour change that is truly permanent??? Thanks for the Youtube video Libby!!  just what I needed right now, my eyebrows and lashes are definitely thinning out more and I am preparing for baldness there.  I think I am finding that harder to come to terms with.  Throwing a headcovering on but still being able to apply make-up as before and look pretty normal is ok but once your lashes and brows go, it gets harder and you definitely can look ill.   I think breast cancer was designed by a man to strip us women of all our dignity and make us humble but little did he realise that in the process of doing this - it makes us stronger in the end!! Ha ha....he (or she) who has the laugh........

Posts.Content: Hi, Don't want to worry you but it does seem Docetaxel has worse side effects than FEC for most people but not all. I had Docetaxel first and my first session was horrendous.  It does not usually hit you until day 3 or 4.  I had sleeplessness because of the steroids, followed by incredible joint pain for which I was subsequenty given gabapentin (it reduced me to tears for 2 days) and then very tired for at least a week.  FEC gave me hardly any problems at all, just slight nausea and headaches within about 4 hours which usually passed within 24 hours.  It may be that you will sail through it but chemo has a cumulative effect anyway, so if you are tired now, just having more chemo will increase that.

Posts.Content: Hi, yes it is a side effect unfortunately.  My finger nails did not get sore but became weak and flakey and came off in layers, they were also very ridged.  I finished chemo 4 weeks ago and they are getting better but my toe nails have not faired so well.  They became thick and yellow (not pleasant looking) but last week, the thick yellow parts of the nails fell off!!  Well some fell off by themselves and the others had a little help!!  Not painful though and in fact they look so much better.  The new nails are already growing back.  Chemo is a poison and your body will suffer in the oddest ways.  I don;t think they outline the side effects well enough when we begin the treatment, there seems to be lots of little, lesser effects that we are not told about or which they 'skim' over.

Posts.Title: Will I be able to work through treatment?

Posts.Content: For a start I would highly recommend the book by Chris Wollams 'Estrogen'.  That gives you a complete low down on how estrogen levels are increased by diet and environmental factors and therefore how you can reduce it by changes to diet and daily practices.  It all depends on how extreme you want to go. I am ER+ too.  I now no longer eat meat (the growth hormones pumped into animals for human consumption increases the Estrogen in our bodies, in addition to that, even with organic meats you are ingesting the animal's own hormons including estrogen), I do eat tofu (I follow the belief that the phytoesteogens are weaker than ours and can help block the receptors so the real baddies have nowhere to go to do any harm and anyway, phyto estrogens can be found in other veggies which are also on the list as 'good' things to eat to combat cancer). Switch to natural skin products if you can.  I now only use products made with shea butter, coconut oil, cocoa butter, aloe vera and the like.  These products are not expensive (sometimes cheaper than brands) and contain no harmful chemicals which can only serve to increase the hormone levels in our bodies as their seep through our skin.  Black soap is the only thing I use in the shower for instance.  You can buy in a block or in liquid form with Vanilla or other natural aromas.  Shea by Nature do some lovely products.  All the chemicals we ingest and slap on our skin are baddies. I even make my own laundry detergent and dishwasher detergent now.  Its not difficult and it cleans great! Check out diynatural.com for ideas. http://www.mybreastcancerjourney.co.uk/hormone-receptor-positive-cancer-how-to-reduce-estrogen-naturally/ A lot of cancer patients follow the Rainbow Diet, also by Chris Wollams.   Hope this makes a good start!!  Let me know if you need any more info.
Posts.Title: My Cancer is ER+ any top tips and advice on what I should avoid in...

Posts.Content: MistyMoley is absolutely right and I am afraid CMulqueen is misinformed.  I have a post-surgery bra which has NO pockets.  It is almost seemless, offered slight compression to the area (for reconstruction), has drop down fronts (a bit like breast feeding bras) so that the breast area can be easily inspected without taking off the whole bra and is front fastening so you dont strain yourself getting it on.  No all post surgery bras have pockets.  It is very much like a sports bra but with all these features and is by Amoena who do post surgery AND mastectomy bras which are not necessarily the same thing. However, due to the fact that I had LD Flap recon, there was some swelling around the back and front and I have been unable to wear it yet but just as Mistmoley said, I would suggest the Ahh bra (Belvia or Genie Bras are the same).  Get a pack of 3 from ebay for £10.  They are indispensible and sooo comfy.  I have been wearing one since 48 hours after surgery and it offers just enough support without interfering with my wounds or sore areas.  I am only a B cup and I understand that the larger you are, the less support they may offer but are still a better option for a few weeks.

Posts.Content: Hi Jamesy, I got a cold a week after my second cycle which was on 12 jan.  It was pretty horrendous and became a chesty/throaty coughing fit kind of cold with lots of mucous.  I kept an eye on my temp, drank plenty of fluids and took echinacea in addition to the other stuff I was taking.  Stay warm, stay inside and just keep an eye on yourself.  Anything that seems different, your temp, if you feel light headed or nauseous then contact your GP or the BCN otherwise you should get through it.  Mine lasted 2 weeks and the mucous on my chest another 2 weeks for which I eventually had to have Mucadyne to shift but I got through it. Above all, don't panic and worry.   X

Don't panic, keep your feet up.  Toddlers are breeding grounds for every infection and virus because they basically have a low immune system, they usually get through it but pass it on to everyone else!!  I believe I caught my cold my my 2 year old as she had a temp the week before and was coughing.  Typical!!

Posts.Content: Hi Mini-moo, You dont say which chemo you are having.  I had Taxotere first and my hair came out in handfuls by day 12 after the first session and within a week after the second it was pretty much all gone (although I had shaved it at that point anyway).  So you may well be better just sticking with what you have at the moment as you may not have enough hair to show any red roots or at the very least because chemo stops the fastest renewing cells (such as hair) you may not get any growth on the hair you have and so not have the roots coming through as you would normally expect to!!

Posts.Content: Flower20, Don't be terrified.  I have a DCIS (originally 8cmx7cm, last measured at 6x5 and has shrunk more since last chemo cycle and will have it examined next week).  I also had an affected lymph node (2cm) in my armpit but my surgeon and my oncologist are absolutely not worried by this.  My surgeon confirmed today that when i have my surgery, the lymph node will simply be removed anyway but it is reacting to chemo and shrinking too.  I thought mine were massive and was shocked but was also told - it is early stage so no problems.  I think it not so much the size of your localised tumours that can be the biggest problem but if you have an aggressive, invasive cancer which likes to 'travel'. There is absolutely nothing to worry about, if you have affected lymph nodes they will ensure your chemo treatments are geared towards that.  Please do not worry.   I had a down week last week but am back up and running again this week.  I have 3 lovely kids and my youngest who is 21/2 is so cute, she is always reminding me why I need to soldier on. As the Chinese say....if worrying is not the solution and worrying will not help find the solution, there is no point in worrying. Get used to the headaches - you will be up and down like a yo-yo over the coming months, but try not to stay low too long. X

Posts.Content: The recommened timing for surgery after chemo is usually between 4 and 11 weeks.  4 weeks being the minimum time it is felt is required for the body to heal enough to endure surgery without increasing the risks and 11 weeks is the maximum as per the government/BMC guidelines to ensure that the cancer does not have time to start growing again.

Posts.Content: It is early Flower20.  Please stop worrying.  The worrying will weaken your immune system even more and let this b****d in! Me too.  I am 5ft 1in, weighed 8st 2lb and worked out (weight training and quite seriously) 4 or 5 times a week depending upon commitments, never ever smoked in my life, drink only moderately and am a big believer in eating healthily (most of the time!) but it got me too.  I have been too tired to work out since August last year and now weigh 9st which I am not happy about.  Muscle is being replaced with fat and none of my clothes fit properly anymore. cancer is not picky.  I personally do not believe that it is just down to diet and lifestyle.  I believe stress plays a big factor in triggering the cancer cells.  Maybe it was the same for you too.  Working, running, being a parent etc etc etc. Maybe demanding too much of your body.   It all takes its toll eventually. Take what you need to get through this but don't let it stop you leading your life.  You will look back in a few months and be furious at the time that has been lost if you do. Pecker up, Flower20.  We are all here in the same boat and the biggest and best thing that gets us through it is preparing to fight. hugs X
Posts.Title: Age 37 shock at breast clinic yesterday. totally dazed and reeling...

Posts.Content: Oh Flower20, what a journey you are on - you have not even got a destination sorted yet which is why you feel lost. Unfortunately, I have to be honest and say 'yes' they may feel there is reason to believe it has spread which is why they are wanting to do the bone and CT scans.  I had them too for that reason.  However, they do so because they need to know if they are treating the cancer correctly so you have a better chance of being cancer-free at the end of it.  My onc told me I can choose not to have the scans and hope that if it has the chemo will kill it off anyway.  however, I said that I had children and that would be very irresponsible of me not to know and not to ensure that I received the appropriate treatment so I went ahead. IF they do find anything and it is an 'IF', they will adjust your treatment accordingly to ensure you get the BEST treatment. As for curable.  They cannot really say that with Cancer at any time.  We all know there is no CURE for cancer yet as Cancer comes in many forms.  It can affect absolutely any part of the body and in many different guises so it is incredibly difficult to cure.  HOWEVER, breast cancer is one of the most easily treatable and gets very good long term results with many women living an additional 10 years+ and some have been known to live 30+ years with no re-occurrence (even with the old treatments). It seems like just when one hurdle has been reduced for you to climb over it, you create another one for yourself.  Don't make yourself worse by fretting over things that may not even happen.  Having cancer is a big enough deal and you seemed to have coped with the news yesterday very well. I personally feel you have a very good diagnosis and there is little to wonder about.  Everything you have has been treated in thousands of other women who are now getting on with their lives cancer-free.  I have a friend whose daughter had leukemia at 4 years old.  that is pretty scary as leukemia travels and lives in the blood so it can go anywhere!  Her daughter is now 24 yrs old and has had no reoccurrence and is healthy and happy.  Please do not fret.  be strong, take it in your stride and deal with this little b*****d head on - it really is the only way.  Look how big and strong you are and how small this cancer is.  Dont feed it with you fear - it just makes it appear bigger and more important than it actually is. All words easily said I know - but you will find yourself fretting all the way through otherwise.  Every time you go for a test you will be fearing the worst and it makes your whole life a misery. We are all here for you Flower20 but only you can take the necessary steps forward in your own journey. Please please please try not to worry.  Worry makes you stressed and affects your immune system and that's how this little parasite got in, in the first place, looking for a weakness to latch onto and feed off.  You really are more in control of how you get through this than you may think.  Being fully informed is the first step - do not fear the results, whatever they are, they give you more power to get through this.
Posts.Title: Age 37 shock at breast clinic yesterday. totally dazed and reeling...

Posts.Content: I am starting this thread as an offshoot to the "stupid things family/friends have said" thread in which MistyMoley suggested this. Its great to have a laugh at the stupid stuff but also nice to smile at the nice (occasional it seems) stuff that people do too, so here is mine. I was offiicially diagnosed on 30 november last year and am a self employed single parent.  I had been unable to work full hours for most of november due to feeling so tired (hence the initial visit to the GP mid november) but by the time I got the news, as with all of us, my head was reeling from the shock and work just disappeared as I struggled to cope with the reality and try and deal with finances.  once I realised that I could not pay all of my nursery fees for my 2 year old (who was in full time then at a monthly cost of £740) for december, I paid £450 that I could afford and notified the nursery that I was unable to give the usual 4 week period notice and pay for it (and told them of my cancer diagnosis) but if they could at least let her attend sessions to the value of my payment and reduce her attendance thereafter until I was through my treatment I would appreciate it and I would try and pay the outstanding amount over the coming couple of months.  Expecting them to be harsh as had been my experience with some nurseries in the past (they always seem to disinterested - the management anyway), I got a shock but a nice one. The Owner of the nursery called me and said 'dont worry - just bring her in as usual this month and we will forget the additional payment and start the reduced attendance from january as per your request.  Please just think of it as our christmas pressie to you and don't get stressed'.  I ended up in tears over the phone which is most unlike the hard, get on with it me. Last month (february), they started offering me a couple of half day additional sessions if I wanted them, and thinking I could do with the time to get some work done or have a rest I took them up on it and paid (with a struggle).  however they then contacted me yet again and said 'no no, the sessions are for free.  We don't have a full quota for that session and it costs us nothing so please don't pay we will take what you have paid off next months bill'  Yet another surprise!! Then yesterday, I had my second fec-100 and felt absolutely dreadful.  My legs felt weak and I felt headachy and nauseous for the first time.  I phoned saying I could not come and get her but would it be ok if my 8 and 10 year old came with the pushchair as I had no other alternative (it is literally 5 mins round the corner).  Pam, the owner, said no don't panic, I will bring her home for you and if you ever have days like this again and either need her collecting for nursery or bringing home, please just ask because you need the rest. So, there ARE good and decent people out there........ I also have to add that I have met some of the nicest people in my chemo unit and oncology waiting room these last 3 months.  People I would never have met otherwise and it does make you realise that not everyone out there is an arrogant so-and-so.  Just one good experience can make all the difference.
Posts.Title: Lovely things that people have done for me

Posts.Content: Flower20,  There is every chance if you leave the house tomorrow that you could get knocked down and end up in hospital.  Will you go out tomorrow?  Of course you will, because the chances are so slim.  So please don't give up on life because of a slim chance it won't happen or you won't succeed. Check this blog for inspiration:  http://emilymcarthur.blogspot.com/2008/12/pregnant-after-cancer.html Cancer WILL take over your life if you let it.  Even when the news seems bleak do not give up or give in. I have a 21/2 year old and for the first time in my life I regretted having her when I was diagnosed because I thought she would end up without a mum and that seemed so selfish of me to have had her.  You cannot base your life plan on what could happen, just go with the flow, deal with life's crap and look forward.  You caught it early and that is really good news.  Stay positive and if anything see this as a wake up call to stop wasting your life and do the things you want to do.   I have.  I have signed up to sit an A level in June (after just 6 mlonths of studying) to get into an OU course I want to do in order to change my career.  I thought about it 2 years ago and did nothing.  Now I am doing something about it. Posts.Content: Hi Lady Muck, As I said in my post, I prefer to live that way because I feel happier feeling that I may be making a difference to my body.  I do not expect that everyone should or would feel the same. I have an engineering background but not a biological one so I do not know if that answers your question as to scientific or not. From what I gather (and I did also say in mypost that I am not an expert, therefore I asked you what you used) that animal feeds DO contain certain things which are intended to promote hormone health for various reasons: "Sow productivity in the UK is increasing dramatically with the introduction of new and superior genetic lines such as the Hampshire and Pietrain. Many herds are now producing 28 pigs per sow per year - the so-called ‘hyper-prolific’ sows. In order to maintain this level of performance correct feeding of the modern sow is vital. Generation Programmed Nutrition is aimed at feeding the next generation of piglets through ‘foetal imprinting’. This helps to re-programme embryonic development to ensure enhanced metabolic competency of the piglet at birth.  Doing so provides the piglet with the best possible start in life, ensuring that not only is it heavier and more vigorous at birth, but subsequently exhibits increased performance during the growing and finisher stages, generating a substantial economic advantage." From a laypersons point of view, if we take a vitamin pill or eat a nutrient rich food, we absorb those vitamins or nutrients into our blood which then go on to feed other cells in our bodies inlcuding muscles, or other tissue.  Does it not therefore follow that if you consume meat, which will by its very nature contain hormones just as our muscle tissue does, you will also be ingesting the nutrients AND the hormones which will then be synthesised by our own bodies? Thats not looking at it from a scientific point but merely a logical one.  And there has been substantial research and studies that have shown that dairy products and animal products do have an effect on our hormone levels including estrogen which in turn have an effect on hormone receptor positive cancers.  I, for one, would like to avoid the things I can to reduce this possibility as there are plenty of things in the environment that I cannot avoid which are also bad for me. Water is another topic altogether.  Tap water has been known to contain levels of estrogen which cannot be removed through the filtering process and although not harmful to most people they do have the potential to increase hormone levels in the individual.  Bottled water can also be a problem depending upon whether its in glass or plastic bottles or whether its simply table water or mineral water/spring water. So, yes, where do you draw the line?  But doing something is better than doing nothing.

Posts.Title: recovery/staying healthy

Posts.Content: Hi, A few things I did which may have helped as I never suffered particularly badly from the chemo (or maybe I was just lucky!) was: Always ensure you have a light meal before going to the chemo treatment.  Once I did it on an empty stomach purely because the appointment started in the morning for the picc insertion and continued through lunch into the afternoon.  I suffered that week. I always took 2 or 3 small bottles of water with me to drink throughout the chemo treatment. Drank at least a 2 litre bottle of water every day for at least a week after the chemo treatment. Make sure when you need to rest, you rest!  Don't put it off.  Feet up and rest, housework or whatever can wait a couple of hours. If you feel headachey or dizzy within hours of the chemo treatment take paracetamol asap, for me it helped to prevent the aches getting unbearable. I would also ask for a bottle of Difflam or similar mouthwash as almost everybody gets a sore mouth to some degree and it can prevent you enjoying or even eating food if it gets too bad.  Ask for this in advance before you leave the treatment room! Make a note of EVERYTHING you suffer or feel after your first cycle.  Any aches, pains etc however insignificant you think they are and NEVER but NEVER hesitate in telling your oncologist that you need pain relief etc.   There is absolutely no need to suffer through the subsequent ones and they do have various pain relievers available for aching joints, nausea etc.  Insist upon them if you really suffered the first time.  If you don't, the remaining cycles will really get you down.  Your body is being poisoned so of course it will react but there is no need to suffer and think it is only a few days I can do it, I am a hero!   Eat little and often and usually lighter meals.  Constipation can be a literal pain for the first few days but can be eased with small regular meals with - yes you guessed it - plenty of fibre.  I found myself becoming particularly fond of pink grapefruit! Hope some of this helps.  If I think of any more I will post. Good luck tomorrow you two.  The time will come and go quicker than you think.  I started my chemo on 22nd Dec last year and thought that the next 5 months would drag, but I don't know where they went!  I am half way through my treatment now, chemo over and surgery next.  I actually feel better than I did before I knew what was wrong with me last year, despite the chemo so I am looking forward to the end of this year. Just look after yourselves, dont overdo anything, you deserve to take a rest while this is happening. XXX
